posts.title: Welcome to My Blog
posts.excerpt: First post on this new site. Building a personal blog with a retro aesthetic inspired by the early web days. Clean, simple, functional.
content: Welcome to my corner of the internet! I'm Reza, an iOS Engineer since 2016, and this is my personal blog where I share thoughts on technology, engineering, and interesting findings.

I decided to build this blog with a retro aesthetic inspired by the early web days. No fancy frameworks, no build steps, no npm packages to maintain. Just plain HTML, CSS, and a sprinkle of JavaScript.
═══ WHY RETRO? ═══

There's something beautiful about the simplicity of 90s web design. Back then, websites were about content first. No cookie banners, no newsletter popups, no autoplaying videos. Just information, clearly presented.
This blog is my attempt to capture that spirit while still being functional and readable on modern devices.
═══ WHAT TO EXPECT ═══

I'll be writing about iOS engineering, software architecture, and the occasional deep-dive into interesting technical problems I encounter. Having shipped over 10,000 releases for different apps, I've seen a lot of patterns—both good and bad.
Stay tuned, and thanks for visiting!

posts.title: The Beauty of Simple Web Design
posts.excerpt: Thoughts on why minimalist web design still works. Sometimes less really is more. No frameworks, no build steps, just HTML and CSS.
content: The modern web is bloated. A simple blog post often requires megabytes of JavaScript, dozens of HTTP requests, and a small data center to render. This got me thinking: why?
═══ THE 90S HAD IT RIGHT ═══
When the web was young, constraints bred creativity. Limited bandwidth meant every byte counted. Limited browser capabilities meant focusing on what mattered: content.
A typical 90s webpage was:
• Fast to load (even on a 56k modem)
• Easy to navigate
• Focused on content
• Accessible by default
═══ MODERN BLOAT ═══
Today's average webpage is over 2MB. That's larger than the entire game DOOM (1993). Think about that for a moment.
We've traded simplicity for complexity, content for tracking scripts, speed for analytics. The user experience often suffers.
═══ FINDING BALANCE ═══
I'm not suggesting we abandon all progress. Modern CSS gives us responsive design. JavaScript enables interactivity. But we should be intentional about what we add.
This blog uses Tailwind via CDN and a bit of jQuery. That's it. No React, no webpack, no node_modules folder with 500MB of dependencies.
Sometimes, less really is more.
